text.tspan: 1. Mix the flour, salt and baking
powder together gently and
thoroughly.
2. Add a little of the water
and mix to a soft pliable dough,
adding a little water at a time to
get the right consistency, you may
not need all of the water and while
you can add more, you can't remove
it, knead the dough for a couple
of minutes.
3. Take the ball of dough on a lightly
floured surface, tear it into
4 equally sized pieces.
4. Roll each piece into a ball using
the palms of your hands.
5. Flatten the balls into rounds,
you could use a rolling pin or just
use your hands to press them
outwards, thin is good here so
they cook quickly, they should be
about 5mm or 1/4" thick.
6. Place a piece of butter, about
10g into a frying pan and turn to
a high heat. Some recipes will state
that you should melt the butter
and add it to the flour mix before
kneading, the choice is yours, I find
this more straightforward and
makes the dough easier to use,
Cut the butter into pieces and
use one per bannock as they
will soak it all up during the
cooking process leaving little
for the next one.
7. Add your uncooked bannock
and leave for about 2 minutes,
use a spatula to lift and turn it
over, they stiffen as they cook
making them easier to handle.
Don't worry if it's not cooked
enough, you can always turn it
over again so that both sides
are cooked evenly.
8. Remove and serve or stack
on a plate while you cook the
others.
